name: Phenylalanine
summary: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid and precursor to neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine, with potential applications in mood regulation, pain management, and cognitive health.
description: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid obtained through dietary protein and supplements. It exists in three forms: L-phenylalanine (naturally occurring and proteinogenic), D-phenylalanine (a synthetic form with potential analgesic properties), and DL-phenylalanine (a mixture of both, used in mood and pain support). Phenylalanine serves as a precursor to tyrosine, which in turn contributes to the synthesis of catecholamine neurotransmitters dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. These pathways make it a target of interest in conditions involving low mood, attention deficits, and chronic pain. However, its use requires caution, especially in individuals with phenylketonuria (PKU).

metadata.natural_source: Protein-rich foods (meat, fish, dairy, legumes, nuts, seeds)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric indications)

primary_indications: Nutritional support in low protein intake
off_label_uses: Possible role in Parkinson’s disease (neurotransmitter precursor)
Supportive use in vitiligo (tyrosine/dopamine pathway link)
contraindications: History of schizophrenia or psychosis (may exacerbate symptoms)
monitoring_required: Liver function in high-dose or long-term use

items: May improve low mood and depressive symptoms
Used in pain management (especially chronic pain with D-phenylalanine)

sections.text: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine, which serves as a precursor for dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. L-phenylalanine primarily supports neurotransmitter synthesis, D-phenylalanine may inhibit enkephalinase enzymes to prolong the activity of endorphins and enkephalins, and DL-phenylalanine combines both mechanisms, potentially offering mood and pain support.

adult.note: DLPA is often used for pain or mood support; L-phenylalanine more for neurotransmitter precursor support.

sections.pediatric: Not recommended as a supplement due to PKU risk.

sections.text: Mood and energy benefits may emerge within days to weeks. Analgesic effects of D-phenylalanine may appear sooner (within days).

serious: Exacerbation of psychosis or mania in vulnerable individuals

other: May increase blood pressure at high doses.
Caution in individuals with psychiatric disorders (mania, psychosis).

sections.pregnancy: Safety not established; avoid unless prescribed
sections.geriatrics: Use cautiously; monitor blood pressure and psychiatric symptoms

sections.text: No formal tapering required, but gradual reduction may help monitor for recurrence of symptoms.

items: DL-phenylalanine is the most common supplement form used for mood and pain applications.
May worsen anxiety or agitation in sensitive individuals.
Historically studied as an adjunctive therapy in depression, though evidence is limited compared to conventional treatments.

items.label: Birkmayer W, et al. DL-phenylalanine in depression. Lancet. 1975
Clinical Pain Review – D-Phenylalanine as an analgesic

seo.title: Phenylalanine – Amino Acid Supplement for Mood and Pain Support
seo.description: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid and precursor to dopamine and norepinephrine, studied for mood, attention, and pain management. Learn about benefits, dosing, and safety.
